body: Thanks @milleruntime I appreciate your prompt help on this! Will keep you posted if we see any other occurrences.

> Thanks @milleruntime I appreciate your prompt help on this! Will keep you posted if we see any other occurrences.

No problem.  FYI I just pushed the second part of the fix in 1fe2705.  With both commits, the issue should be fixed now.
@EdColeman are you currently working on this task? If not, do you mind if I give it a go?

@SlickNik Here is the current changeset https://github.com/phrocker/accumulo/compare/master...nativeupdates2x?expand=1

Note that I've brought in two dependencies. One is a lock free concurrent queue that will facilitate work down the road to improve concurrency of native maps in general but it also allows me to use a singleton pattern for memory delegation. I'm performing some benchmarks now, but in contrived tests I see improvements; however, the ultimate test will be with more realistic work loads. I need to clean the branch up and add some of my tests. I'd like to move to cmake so the two added third party dependencies can be downloaded; however, I may make that a follow on task.
I'll do some cleanup tomorrow morning then submit a WIP PR so you all can take a look in a PR.
Another option would be to drop this class altogether and have the lexicoders implement the Lexicoder interface directly
I'm working fate metrics, but have not started this.

@etseidl Thanks. I see you created this, and then immediately created a PR within minutes. For future reference, it is not necessary to create a separate issue since, on GitHub, PRs are also issues and have their own trackable issue number. Sometimes it is useful to have a separate issue to track a problem before a fix is complete, but you can often skip that if it's not necessary, since we don't require it.
@ctubbsii sorry, I wasn't sure if this one would turn into a bigger fix.  Thanks for the info.

Thanks for pushing this up @phrocker! I've pulled down the changes from your branch and should have some time to go through them over the next day or two. I haven't yet looked at how this is all being built, so I may have some more questions as I do that - maybe the move to cmake is something that I can help with as well, as I look into this.
I'm still making some changes as I noticed a few issues/bugs/improvements but happy to dive into. Happy to have help with cmake. It would make things much easier.

I've been working on the back-port and being that the underlying code in this test is shared with the fate concurrency and fate metrics, I've been running the 3 IT tests each time, and that's when this began to fail. It was fine stand-alone and in the IDE.  Being that the file is created by the metrics subsystem, it seemed preferable to treat the metrics subsystem as the "owner" and then just deal with it.

If anybody has questions about how the native map builds currently work, I can probably answer those... although I think it's relatively simple: Essentially, we have a maven module that, instead of producing a jar at the package phase, produces a tarball containing a `Makefile` and our C++ sources (including those generated from `javac -h` earlier in the multi-module maven build). This tarball is included inside the `-bin.tar.gz` distribution file for users to extract and build for their platform. I think we provide a convenience script to unpack and call `make` for them (in case `tar xvf ... && cd ... && make` is too hard :smiley_cat:)

You can see this tarball by running `mvn clean package -DskipTests` and looking at `server/native/target/accumulo-native-*.tar.gz`

I would be interested in understanding the benefits of moving to `cmake`. As I understand it, most of the benefits come from the ability to reduce the usage of other autotools/configure stuffs, but we don't use any of that. We just have a *very* trivial `Makefile`.

The focus is on user-buildability, rather than providing pre-built native binaries. If we do switch to `cmake`, it seems like something that could happen as its own independent task, but I would want to maintain our current practice of making it user-buildable, rather than pre-building binaries.

> @ctubbsii sorry, I wasn't sure if this one would turn into a bigger fix. Thanks for the info.

No worries. That is one of many perfectly legitimate reasons to create an issue first. :smiley_cat: . I just wanted to make sure you (and others) don't do it because you think you *have to* (as some holdover from JIRA days, for example).
It's okay to have *impl* imports. It's just not okay for them to expose those types in their public/protected members. apilyzer-maven-plugin should catch violations of this.
We should probably move system iterators out of the way, because those should not be public API, but otherwise, I think this is fine.

> I had some reservations initially, because there's already two type hierarchies in the lexicoder package for public API, and I wasn't sure if this would complicate things, but I now think it's probably fine.

I am leaning towards just removing the class since it is in the impl package and we don't need both.

@ctubbsii I agree that the make file is relatively simple, but I'm afraid it's not about simplicity. 

In the case where you have external projects that you are linking and using ( in my branch I am ), there is an ExternalProject command which not only simplifies that but helps ensures that you don't link incorrectly. It also helps avoiding pollution of your source especially when you are only including it in binary form ( as we are ). 

Additionally, I saw some version specific variables embedded in the make file. This can go away because CMAKE takes all of that into account and automates the generation of your make file. 

Even more so we use -O3...frankly we should be allowing this to be 
overridden. There are other modes ( -Os if that were preferred in certain deployments ) that have practical applications. As a rule of thumb we should probably use a lower optimization level ( -O2 versus -O3 ) level with select flags specified. My hope is to prove this via google benchmark. Managing those flags across GCC versions would be simpler with CMAKE, because that is part of its job. 

The final point is that adding dependencies like google bench mark and google test would be far simpler with CMAKE for not only the reason above, but because we can manage those dependencies. I'm certainly not suggesting we take a stab at the cmake in this issue, but I included two additional dependencies and added them to a "thirdparty" directory That's not unreasonable, but those source files do not need to be included even by way of a git sub module. ExternalProject is preferred IMO. 

In the same vein as google benchmark I did some tests with jemalloc which showed dramatic improvement in certain use cases. Showing those benchmarks and allowing a static link into the SO would be ideal and much easier with CMAKE. All of this can be done with make, but why reinvent the wheel?

Your point of "we just have a very trivial Makefile" is spot on, but when you begin to change that, using prior work versus writing our own allocator for example, I think the argument for cmake begins to gain traction. Further, as you integrate things like google benchmark to prove, then keeping the Makefile is more an effort in adding work, complexity, and hidden bugs than incorporating something that has minimal impact. It would be stated that this would be totally transparent to the user and a feature inherently supported by maven's infra.
The final point to make is that cmake is inherently simpler and shorter, so when the initial dev moves onward or is unavailable, supporting fixes to the cmake lists file will be easier.
Possibly. We may decide to not do 2.0.x bugfix releases (treat it as non-LTS... see mailing list discussion).
Ah, I didn't read far enough in the proposal.  I don't think this is critical enough since the bind address can be passed in on the CL.  Won't be hurt if you just close it.

Okay, let's just close it then, since it's easy to mitigate. We can always reopen and backport if really needed, but this keeps the git history slightly cleaner if we don't need the commit in the history twice.

Those are all very good reasons to use cmake. I'm not opposed. I just want to understand the benefits.

I do wonder if it's a good idea to add third party dependencies to code which is currently very small, and has very minimal dependencies. Even if it's a performance benefit... or a maintenance benefit (less code)... it may not be worth the trade off. It'd be nice if that could be done as an independent task.

As I see it, there are 3 things being discussed (and worked on) here:

1. Change the build system for the native code (make -> cmake and/or improvements to the hard-coded flags in the Makefile)
2. Modernize the code (using more recent C++ standards)
3. Reduce some of our custom code with third party libraries that do the job better

In my opinion, all three of these are possibly good improvements, but they should be decoupled from one another. We're talking about making all these changes at once, and I think they each have their own pros and cons, and they should be done completely independently. That will help facilitate code reviews, and discussions about pros/cons of specific change proposals.

@ctubbsii to be fair I'm not proposing cmake at this time or for this task. I'm only doing task two(modernization) but the fallout is that item three is quite natural (avoiding custom code, where other code is maintained to avoid bugs with compilers, is cross platform, etc. ) I'm excluding Google benchmark and anything else mentioned above at this time due to not wanting to handle dependencies in make and natural separation of duties that and I and other developers naturally perform .
 

The scope of this issue will be quite limited.

> > I had some reservations initially, because there's already two type hierarchies in the lexicoder package for public API, and I wasn't sure if this would complicate things, but I now think it's probably fine.
> 
> I am leaning towards just removing the class since it is in the impl package and we don't need both.

After looking into this, I discovered that all the lexicoder tests use this class so I think moving it is fine.

@ctubbsii Totally agree that issue 1 is orthogonal to 2 and 3. There may be some coupling between 2 and 3 (in some cases where the more modern code may depend on 3rd party libs) - and @phrocker has more visibility to that than I do, so he is in a better position to talk about that.

Also agree that it's a good idea tackle a move to cmake, or any other such build improvements separately. That will make for easier separation of concerns during  discussions, reviews, etc.
I think it should be a goal to minimize the coupling between 2 and 3, if it can be done, but understand that it may not be possible (or sensible).

I've seen this before, but it has always been transient, only showing up in the first few seconds of starting the monitor, before the monitor has any data populated, and then it goes away. I'm not sure what's going on with it, but it's probably some formatting error for very tiny (effectively zero) double values, possibly in the denominator to some division problem in the monitor code.

I looked into trying to block against this behavior and I don't think it is worth trying to prevent.  We could check for small values but it is possible the rates could be small so it would be difficult to determine what is valid. This only happens during the first few seconds at the start of a new cluster.

One option might be to delay presentation of the data until at least 5 or 10 seconds have passed since the server started, so that the monitor can have enough time to produce numbers that make more sense. That could be done in the client-side javascript, or as some special case in the monitor server code that sends the data used.
Thank you both for sharing your perspective on this. It would be a good exercise for me to look into what Christopher mentioned, so let me do that.
I moved this PR to be based on the master branch instead of 2.0, since we're removing the 2.0 branch as discussed on the mailing list.
As discussed on the mailing list, 2.0 isn't planned to be an LTS release, so there's no need to backport to that branch (the branch is going to be removed).
Could these just be rounded to an integer?

> If we are going to try to get this into public API, I think it would make sense to have blocker 2.1 issues for the work to be done. Could have and issue for apilyzer and one for doc updates.

TODO after merge.

@keith-turner you resolved the comments about multiple volumes, but that got me looking more deeply at how the volume chooser works.  Would it make more sense to add a getAllVolumesForPath() that returns an array of Volumes and then loop over those? Maybe pass in a scope as well?  I'm thinking not just about this PR, but looking ahead to the changes I want to make to add EC support at the table config level.

> @keith-turner you deleted the comments about multiple volumes

I didn't delete it, I just resolved the conversation.  It still here (but collapsed) you just have to find it and click `Show resolved` to expand it.

> Would it make more sense to add a getAllVolumesForPath()

Not sure exactly how you are thinking of using it.

I was thinking of adding something like String[] chooseAll(env, options) to the VolumeChooser interface.  This would probably have to made visible through the VolumeManager interface as well.  Then at tserver start up I'd get the list of paths that would be valid for the LOGGER scope, and check each one individually.

The individual log file checks in DfsLogger would be unchanged.

> I was thinking of adding something like String[] chooseAll(env, options) to the VolumeChooser interface.

Ok.  That seems like the only thing that would work to solve this problem.  Could possible call the method `String[] choosable(env, options)`  Would have to consider what if anything can be done for backward compat.
Sounds like a plan.

> Sounds like a plan.

Should this be merged first, and that done as a separate, follow-on action?

Having a delay would work, I am just not sure where in the code would be the best place.  It would probably be overly complicated to try and do it in the javascript.  Perhaps in the constructor of the Monitor.

Rounding to an integer would work but we would lose precision during slower ingest rates.  Although, I'm not sure how much difference < 1MB would make...

> Should this be merged first, and that done as a separate, follow-on action?

I think so because it would involve changing the volume chooser
need to slightly modify my regex to pickup getBytes(UTF_8) also.  Will create a new PR
Ok, I'll start working on the volume chooser changes in a new branch.
I modified my command to also catch `UTF_8`, reopened this, and then force pushed.

>  Although, I'm not sure how much difference < 1MB would make...

Would be nice to keep some precision.   Could do `(long)(d * 1000)/1000.0` where `d` is a double to truncate `d` to a few decimal places.

Flot has options for displaying the axes:
https://github.com/flot/flot/blob/master/API.md#customizing-the-axes

In particular, the `tickDecimals` and the `tickFormatter` are probably what we should be changing.

Our plots are generated in `overview.js`: https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/d5012048609e2c8d567a5a9b652230d36a607f19/server/monitor/src/main/resources/org/apache/accumulo/monitor/resources/js/overview.js

This was done in #1264
Any attempt at this may not catch all instances and that is ok.

I looked into this a bit today.  Another issue I discovered with ZooLock's use of ZooReader is that it automatically creates new Zookeeper objects when a session has expired.  I am not sure if this is causing any problems, but its a concern I have.  The following is some background info.

 * Zookeeper objects have a one to relationship with a zookeeper session.  When a session expires zookeeper objects become non-functional.
 * Zoolock relies on ephemeral nodes which are automatically deleted when a session expires.

It may be ok that new Zookeeper objects are automatically created because the ephemeral node will cease to exist and this would be visible through the new zookeeper object.

Because of the tight coupling between zoolock, ephemeral nodes, zookeeper objects, and zookeeper sessions I think it may be better if zoolock directly uses zookeeper w/o any intermediate abstraction layer.

I believe this is ready for merge, just waiting to see if there are any additional comments since removing the draft status.  The some of the test improvements that were originally here have already been merged into 1.9 and brought forward with the SlowOps and FateConcurrencyIT rework.

I modified the core/pom.xml as so:
```
-                <include>org[.]apache[.]accumulo[.]core[.]iterators[.]IteratorUtil[$]IteratorScope</include>
+                <include>org[.]apache[.]accumulo[.]core[.]iterators[.].*</include>
```
And saw the following failures:
```
  METHOD_RETURN        org.apache.accumulo.core.iterators.IteratorEnvironment       getServiceEnv(...)                  org.apache.accumulo.core.spi.common.ServiceEnvironment
  FIELD                org.apache.accumulo.core.iterators.user.VisibilityFilter     cache                               org.apache.commons.collections4.map.LRUMap
  FIELD                org.apache.accumulo.core.iterators.user.TransformingIterator log                                 org.slf4j.Logger
```
I added the first method to IteratorEnvironment as a replacement for AccumuloConfiguration.  It seems that SPI has now entered into the quasi-API limbo, where iterators have lived for some time.  Perhaps SPI should be declared as public API along with iterators.  Even if SPI doesn't affect data like iterators do, it has a nice way to access server configuration.

It seems like the LRUMap was made protected so users could override it with a different implementation. Whatever the case, I think this type could be a java.util.Map.

The logger should probably just be private.
Seems like ZooCache.getChildren may still set watchers.

Could add an "allows" line for the service environment instead of promoting it to public API. It might be okay to have it leak into the public API, as long as it's documented carefully, and just treat it as an excepted case.
(To be clear, I think this is a good idea short-term, but I think it'd be better long-term to get the upstream devs in those communities to properly mark their optional dependencies.)

I will work on this
Started taking a look at this during Accumulo hack day. Will work on this.
I will attempt to fix this issue.

After some discussion with @keith-turner and @ctubbsii, I think we should treat iterators as SPI.  They are pluggable server mechanisms, that can be affected by internal server changes, similar to the other plugins in the SPI.   I think, along with the other SPI packages, we should only guarantee compatibility across bug fix versions.
Based on some discussion in #1415, iterators may need to be treated as SPI instead.

>  Perhaps SPI should be declared as public API along with iterators.

Pluggable interfaces in SPI related to scan execution and caching are tightly coupled to Accumulo's internal model for executing scans.  If these interfaces are in the API it could make it very difficult to change the internal execution model for scans.  The reason is because it may require going through a deprecation cycle where a single release supports an old and new model of executing scans, which may not be practical.  Also the interfaces related to scan execution and caching only impact scan performance, never scan data returned.

> They are pluggable server mechanisms, that can be affected by internal server changes, similar to the other plugins in the SPI.

I thought it made sense to place iterators in the public API because they can change the data returned by scans and are tightly coupled to a users data and queries.  I can take a stab at this.
All ITs are passing now with this fix to the change
I created a draft PR #1426 where I attempted to pull iterators in to the API from Apilyzer perspective.  I also attempted to document/define SPI in that PR.

This could be follow on work and I think these would go hand in hand.  Instead of just watching a single node, we could watch 10 or 20 nodes and hash properties between them in some way.  My thinking is that this may handle high frequency changes more gracefully.  I also think it would be better to pull this code out of ZooCache into its own class.  Something like TablePropertyCache.  Having it in its own class would make it easier to make changes like the hashing thing.  Also I think it would be easier to understand ZooCache and TablePropertyCache if separate.  Again this can be follow on work.

I agree with your comment above.  The high frequency changes concern me also.  When you see in the logs that the code is actually processing the changes in the proper consecutive order it is pretty amazing.  In a large network with a little latency the watch events might not inform all the tservers as perfectly as they do on a 5 node cluster in EC2.

> Looks good so far. I wouldn't be opposed to dropping `getServiceEnv()` altogether since it hasn't been around very long and technically was never in the API.

Good point. :+1: from me.
Hello, I would like to work on this if it's still available. Thanks!
Sure @Jman24 .   Let me know if you have any questions.

I marked this issue as a "good first issue", because adding the limit is relatively simple. However, the code changes are in an area that may be somewhat unfriendly to approach, so it's slightly more challenging than other possible "good first issues". Perhaps this might be a "good second issue". Either way, it's a small amount of code to be changed and should be easy to implement and create simple test cases for.
Upon completion of this issue, a good follow-up PR would be to implement the same restrictions in the size of namespace names.

This issue is marked a "good first issue" because it doesn't really involve any code, just class path and build tooling. However, it will likely require some familiarity with Maven, the maven-assembly-plugin, and class paths in general. It will also be best if the contributor who works on this already knows how to run Accumulo, say in [Uno](https://github.com/apache/fluo-uno), for testing.

>  the code changes are in an area that may be somewhat unfriendly to approach

@ctubbsii where do you think a change should be made for this?

Do we know what the impact / actual limit is?  The might be quite a gap between "giant" and  255.  Depending on how tables are created, it is not hard to get larger than 255.  Throw in a base name, a yarn job name and a timestamp or two and you can get a generated name that is not user friendly, but does encode some system runtime info that can be useful.

Whatever limit is "chosen" an approach could to have it as a configuration parameter with a sensible default and some guidance on what the "real" max should be considered to be.  Sort of like the zookeeper jute buffer parameter.
Nevermind @ctubbsii , the information I was asking about is in the description.

@EdColeman I think adding a configuration parameter makes this issue more complex than something I would be comfortable asking a first-time contributor to do. That could be done as a follow-on issue, if it's in high demand. However, I do think we should keep in mind that the table name is primarily for humans, and should be within reason for humans to read, memorize, type in the shell, view on the monitor, see in the logs, etc.

I do think you make a good point about it easy to get above 255, with a naming convention that is composed of a few different external sources. If 1024 is more reasonable than 255, I'd be happy to support that instead.

> @ctubbsii did you grep the codebase for these types of settings?

Yes.

> Seems like ZooCache.getChildren may still set watchers.

My last commit deals with this in TableManager.removeTable by performing this call:
` zoo.getZooKeeper().getChildren(tableConfigPath, false);`

Currently the watched node has a single prop name in its value.  It could have a list in its value and that could be very beneficial for create, clone, and import table. The list could help avoid missing updates.  It may also be useful for deletetable.  It would also better support a future API call that allows setting multiple props at once.

The create table operation knows of all of the props its going to set in zookeeper.  It could set all of those props (without updating the watched node for each prop) and then after setting all, it could set the value of the watched node to the list of props it updated.

> Currently the watched node has a single prop name in its value. It could have a list in its value and that could be very beneficial for create, clone, and import table. The list could help avoid missing updates. It may also be useful for deletetable. It would also better support a future API call that allows setting multiple props at once.
> 
> The create table operation knows of all of the props its going to set in zookeeper. It could set all of those props (without updating the watched node for each prop) and then after setting all, it could set the value of the watched node to the list of props it updated.

That's a great idea.  Do you want me to start implementing that?  Maybe we need an additional TableState enum like CONFIGS_CHANGING?  That is so operations being effected by the config changes can be controlled during the configuration change operation.

> That's a great idea. Do you want me to start implementing that?

It could be done in this PR, if not I can open follow up issues.

> > That's a great idea. Do you want me to start implementing that?
> 
> It could be done in this PR, if not I can open follow up issues.

I will start working on it now then.
